text: General elections were held in Tunisia on 25 October 2009. Official decree of July 7, 2009 Results released on 26 October 2009 indicated a substantial victory for incumbent President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali, who won the reelection for a fifth five-year term, and the governing Constitutional Democratic Rally. It was the last election contested under the Ben Ali regime, prior to the Tunisian Revolution. ==Observers== The African Union sent a team of election observers to cover the election. The delegation was led by Benjamin Bounkoulou who described the election as "free and fair".Tunisian president in fifth win, BBC News, October 26, 2009. However, a spokesperson from the United States State Department indicated that Tunisia did not allow international monitoring of elections, but the U.S. was still committed to working with the president of Tunisia and its government.World datelines , Deseret News, Oct. 27, 2009 There also were reports of mistreatment of an opposition candidate.Opposition leader who gave TV interview in Paris is beaten by police on his return Menassat, October 1st, 2009 ==Results== ===President=== The Interior Ministry released the official results for the election on Monday 26 October 2009.Fifth term for Tunisia's president, Press Association, October 26, 2009. Voter turnout was recorded at 89.40% with 4,447,388 of Tunisia's 5.3 million registered voters participating.A parliamentary majority for the Constitutional Democratic Rally (RCD) with 89.59%, Tunisia Online News, October 26, 2009. In the presidential race, incumbent president Zine El Abidine Ben Ali won 89.62% of the vote. His nearest rivals were Mohamed Bouchiha with 5.01% of the vote and Ahmed Inoubli with 3.80%, and Ahmed Brahum with 1.57%. {| class=wikitable style=text- align:right !colspan=2|Candidate !Party !Votes !% |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Zine El Abidine Ben Ali||align=left|Constitutional Democratic Rally||4,238,711||89.62 |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Mohamed Bouchiha||align=left|Popular Unity Party||236,955||5.01 |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Ahmed Inoubli||align=left|Unionist Democratic Union||179,726||3.80 |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Ahmed Brahim||align=left|Ettajdid Movement||74,257||1.57 |- |align=left colspan=3|Invalid/blank votes||7,718||– |- |align=left colspan=3|Total||4,737,367||100 |- |align=left colspan=3|Registered voters/turnout||5,296,008||89.45 |- |align=left colspan=5|Source: POGAR |} ===Parliament=== In the Chamber of Deputies election, the Democratic Constitutional Rally, which had governed continuously from Tunisia's independence from France in 1956 until the Tunisian Revolution, won 84.59% of the vote and 161 seats. The Movement of Socialist Democrats won 16 seats with 4.63% of the vote, the Popular Unity Party won 12 seats and 3.39% of votes, The Unionist Democratic Union won 9 seats with 2.56%. The remaining 16 seats were divided between the Social Liberal Party, who won eight seats, the Green Party for Progress, who won six and the Movement Ettajdid who won two seats. {| class=wikitable style=text-align:right !colspan=2|Party !Votes !% !Seats !+/– |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Constitutional Democratic Rally||3,754,559||84.59||161||+9 |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Movement of Socialist Democrats||205,374||4.63||16||+2 |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Popular Unity Party||150,639||3.39||12||+1 |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Unionist Democratic Union||113,773||2.56||9||+2 |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Social Liberal Party||99,468||2.24||8||+6 |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Green Party for Progress||74,185||1.67||6||New |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Ettajdid Movement||22,206||0.50||2||−1 |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Democratic Forum for Labour and Liberties||5,329||0.12||0||New |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Progressive Democratic Party||1,412||0.03||0||New |- |bgcolor=| ||align=left|Independent lists||11,552||0.26||0||– |- |align=left colspan=2|Invalid/blank votes||8,891||–||–||– |- |align=left colspan=2|Total||4,447,388||100||214||+25 |- |align=left colspan=2|Registered voters/turnout||4,974,707||89.40||–||– |- |align=left colspan=6|Source: POGAR |} ==References== ==External links== *Presidential and Legislative Elections in Tunisia - 2009 ===Media=== *Ben Ali reelected with 89 per cent - Radio France Internationale *Unsurprising victory for Ben Ali - Radio France Internationale *Final results give President Ben Ali a fifth term - France 24 *Ben Ali wins unsurprising landslide in presidential election - France 24 Tunisia Category:Elections in Tunisia Category:2009 in Tunisia Category:Presidential elections in Tunisia Category:October 2009 events in Africa
title: 2009 Tunisian general election
